articles.headline: U.S. Planning to Slash Iraq Embassy Staff by as Much as Half
articles.snippet: The swift realization that the diplomatic buildup may have been ill advised is a remarkable pivot for the State Department.
articles.abstract: The swift realization that the diplomatic buildup may have been ill advised is a remarkable pivot for the State Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Less than two months after American troops left, the State Department is preparing to slash by as much as half the enormous diplomatic presence it had planned for Iraq, a sharp sign of declining American influence in the country.

articles.headline: As Growth Slows, India Awakens to Need for Foreign Investment
articles.snippet: India’s central bank and economic analysts predict that growth will fall sharply to 7 percent this fiscal year and remain sluggish.
articles.abstract: India’s central bank and economic analysts predict that growth will fall sharply to 7 percent this fiscal year and remain sluggish.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When India’s finance minister, Pranab Mukherjee, flew to Chicago recently to address a group of American executives, it was to deliver an urgent message: India is still open for business.

articles.headline: Court Strikes Down Ban on Gay Marriage in California
articles.snippet: The decision by a federal appeals court panel that Proposition 8 violated people’s rights all but ensured that the case would proceed to the United States Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: The decision by a federal appeals court panel that Proposition 8 violated people’s rights all but ensured that the case would proceed to the United States Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A federal appeals court panel on Tuesday threw out a voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage passed in 2008, upholding a lower court’s ruling that the ban, known as Proposition 8, violated the constitutional rights of gay men and lesbians in California.

articles.headline: A Contrarian Bets Ireland and Hungary Will Rebound
articles.snippet: Michael Hasenstab, whose Franklin Templeton Global Bond Fund owns billions in Irish and Hungarian bonds, is drawing comparisons to the giants of the mutual fund industry.
articles.abstract: Michael Hasenstab, whose Franklin Templeton Global Bond Fund owns billions in Irish and Hungarian bonds, is drawing comparisons to the giants of the mutual fund industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months now, a big investor has been betting billions of dollars that two of Europe’s most wounded countries will bounce back from the beating they have taken during the region’s debt crisis.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Santorum Upsets G.O.P. Race With Three Victories
articles.snippet: Rick Santorum won the Minnesota and Colorado caucuses and a nonbinding primary in Missouri on Tuesday, raising fresh questions about Mitt Romney’s ability to corral conservative support.
articles.abstract: Rick Santorum won the Minnesota and Colorado caucuses and a nonbinding primary in Missouri on Tuesday, raising fresh questions about Mitt Romney’s ability to corral conservative support.
articles.lead_paragraph: His candidacy all but dismissed just days ago, Rick Santorum won the Minnesota and Colorado caucuses and a nonbinding primary in Missouri on Tuesday, an unexpected trifecta that raised fresh questions about Mitt Romney’s ability to corral conservative support.

articles.headline: In Data Deluge, Multitaskers Go to Multiscreens
articles.snippet: In a new tactic for countering the data assault, offices are giving workers a second computer screen and sometimes a third.
articles.abstract: In a new tactic for countering the data assault, offices are giving workers a second computer screen and sometimes a third.
articles.lead_paragraph: Workers in the digital era can feel at times as if they are playing a video game, battling the barrage of e-mails and instant messages, juggling documents, Web sites and online calendars. To cope, people have become swift with the mouse, toggling among dozens of overlapping windows on a single monitor.

articles.headline: The Piracy Problem: How Broad?
articles.snippet: Media and Internet giants at odds over dealing with purloined content on the Web may need to agree first on exactly how bad the problem is.
articles.abstract: Media and Internet giants at odds over dealing with purloined content on the Web may need to agree first on exactly how bad the problem is.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Fred Wilson, a prominent New York venture capitalist who has backed Twitter and Zynga, wanted to watch the Knicks game last month, he got an unpleasant surprise. Time Warner Cable was not showing the game because of a contract dispute.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Amy Chozick
